one_liner: TUS is a non-invasive technique that uses ultrasound waves to modulate neuronal activity in deep brain structures.
how_it_works: TUS employs a 256-element transducer array to deliver focused ultrasound waves to specific brain regions. By adjusting parameters such as frequency and pulse duration, it can precisely modulate neuronal activity. Real-time fMRI monitoring allows researchers to observe the effects of stimulation and adjust parameters accordingly for optimal results.

steps: 1. Position participant using a custom-designed stereotactic mask.
2. Use low-dose CT scans to derive participant-specific skull and brain properties.
3. Compute driving parameters for each transducer element using a full-wave acoustic model.
4. Apply TUS to the target area with specified pulse parameters.
5. Monitor brain activity using fMRI during and after stimulation.
6. Adjust stimulation parameters in real-time based on feedback.
algorithm.core_equation: output = modulated neuronal activity in targeted brain regions
algorithm.input_format: Participant-specific anatomical data from CT scans and fMRI imaging.
algorithm.output_format: Modulated neuronal activity in targeted brain regions, observed through fMRI.

parameters.name: frequency
parameters.effect: Higher frequencies may enhance spatial resolution but could also increase tissue heating.

parameters.name: target pressure
parameters.effect: Increasing pressure may enhance stimulation effects but risks damaging tissue.

parameters.name: pulse duration
parameters.effect: Longer pulse durations may lead to stronger modulation but could also cause discomfort.

parameters.name: pulse interval
parameters.effect: Shorter intervals may increase stimulation frequency but could lead to fatigue.

parameters.name: theta burst stimulation duration
parameters.effect: Longer durations may enhance cumulative effects but risk overstimulation.

parameters.name: theta burst frequency
parameters.effect: Higher frequencies may lead to more rapid modulation but could also reduce precision.

complexity.time: O(n) where n is the number of transducer elements
complexity.space: O(m) where m is the size of the anatomical data
complexity.practical_note: Real-world performance may vary based on individual anatomical differences.

use_when: You need to target deep brain structures non-invasively.
You want to study the effects of neuromodulation on brain function.
You are developing therapies for neurological disorders.
avoid_when: You are targeting superficial cortical regions with high angles of incidence.
implementation_skeleton:
def apply_tus(ct_data: CTData, fMRI_data: fMRIData) -> NeuronalActivity:
    position_participant(ct_data)
    derive_skull_properties(ct_data)
    compute_transducer_parameters()
    apply_ultrasound_stimulation()
    monitor_brain_activity(fMRI_data)
    adjust_parameters_real_time()
    return modulated_activity
common_mistakes: Not accounting for individual anatomical variations in skull and brain structure.
Using inappropriate stimulation parameters that do not match the target area.
Failing to monitor real-time feedback during stimulation.

strengths: Non-invasive method for deep brain stimulation.
Ability to monitor effects in real-time using fMRI.
weaknesses: Limited to deep brain structures; less effective for superficial areas.
Potential for discomfort or adverse effects if not properly calibrated.

compared_to.verdict: Use TUS for deeper brain structures; use TMS for superficial areas.
